newsitem.title: USA: Longest-serving Sen. Thurmond not slowing down.
newsitem.headline: Longest-serving Sen. Thurmond not slowing down.

text.p: At age 94, on the brink of becoming the longest-serving senator ever, Strom Thurmond says daily exercise, morning prunes and a zest for life keep him going every day.
A stalwart conservative symbol of Deep South politics for more than a half-century, Thurmond last year became the oldest ever senator.
This Sunday, he adds another longevity mark, becoming the longest-serving senator in American history, surpassing the 42-year record set by Carl Hayden of Arizona on Jan. 2, 1969.
Thurmond plans on marking the day by giving a speech back home in South Carolina, not far from Edgefield, where he was born in 1902.
Many around the Capitol believe Thurmond is past his prime and his chairmanship of the Armed Services Committee is semi-ceremonial, with younger colleagues doing the hard work.
But saying the felt "like a million dollars," he held an energetic and funny news conference Thursday celebrating the milestone, and said he has given no thought to retirement.
"I intend to serve my term out," he said, meaning he could mark his 100th birthday in office.
Thurmond said he rises each day and does 20 minutes of calisthenics, including pushups, followed by 20 minutes on a stationary bike and some stretching.
Breakfast religiously includes "a half-banana, a half-apple, prunes and grapes." He fills out the meal, alternating between oatmeal one day, and artifical eggs, grits and cheese the next.

Thurmond doesn't just show up in the Senate every day. He shows up early. He is president pro tempore of the Senate -- a largely ceremonial post that puts him third in line for presidential succession after the vice president and speaker of the House -- and he opens the Senate session every day.
His genes, he acknowledged, probably have something to do with his vigour. That, he said, "and an optimistic attitude toward life."
